explanation: Uses checksum-based change detection to only exfiltrate modified browser profile data, reducing redundant transfers in an automated manner (T1020).
rationale_steps: Select browser data likely to contain sensitive artifacts.
Quiet, compressed synchronization to a concealed path.
Avoids repeated transfers of unchanged files.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Valid rsync syntax with correct flags, environment variable expansion, and a properly formed SSH remote destination path.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command uses rsync with compression and checksum-based delta transfer to send browser profile data to a remote host, aligning with automated exfiltration behavior, though scheduling/automation is not inherent to this single invocation.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The rsync command is perfectly well-formed with valid flags (-azq, --checksum), proper variable usage ($HOME, $HOSTNAME), and correct source/destination syntax.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1020 (Automated Exfiltration) as it uses rsync to efficiently transfer only modified browser profile data to a remote server using checksum verification, making it an ideal tool for automated, scheduled exfiltration.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, uses valid flags, correct variable expansion, and a standard rsync source/destination format with no syntax errors.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly achieves the claimed intent of automated, checksum-based exfiltration of browser profile data to an external location, directly aligning with MITRE ATT&CK T1020.
